The '''''Amazonas'' class''' are three [[Patrol boat|Offshore Patrol Vessels]] (OPVs) built by [[VT Group|VT Shipbuilding]] (now [[BAE Systems Surface Ships]]). The ships entered service with the [[Brazilian Navy]] during 2012 and 2013.
==Design and build==
The vessels are based on the [[Royal Navy]]'s {{sclass2|River|patrol vessel|2}}, are 90m long, and have 80 man crews plus accommodation for 40 troops.<ref name="Article in Naval Recognition">{{cite web |title=Third BAE Systems built OPV for Brazilian Navy "ARAGUARI" handed over during ceremony |publisher= Naval Recognition |date= 22 June 2013 |url=http://www.navyrecognition.com/index.php/news/defence-news/year-2013-news/june-2013-navy-world-naval-forces-maritime-industry-technology-news/1097-third-bae-systems-built-opv-for-brazilian-navy-qaraguariq-handed-over-during-ceremony.html |accessdate=2014-08-18}}</ref> They are designed to perform a range of [[Economic Exclusion Zone]] (EEZ) management, special operations and maritime law enforcement tasks.
The first vessel was named ''Port of Spain'' at her launch, at [[BAE Systems Surface Ships]]’ Portsmouth facility, on 18 November 2009.
The second was named ''Scarborough'' on her launch a day later at [[Scotstoun]] in [[Glasgow]], and began sea trials in July 2010, reaching 25.38 knots.<ref name="Article in Trinidad & Tobago Newsday">{{cite web |title=Scarborough is ship-shape |publisher= Trinidad & Tobago Newsday |date= 8 September 2010 |url=http://www.newsday.co.tt/crime_and_court/0,127187.html |accessdate=2014-08-18}}</ref>
The third was named ''San Fernando'' when launched on 16 July 2010 at Scotstoun on the River Clyde.<ref>{{cite web |title=Trindad & Tobago Ships Sail into the Clyde for First Sea Trials |publisher=defpro |year=2010 |url=http://www.defpro.com/news/details/16798/ |accessdate=2010-07-18}}</ref>
==Operators==
The ''Amazonas'' class were originally named as the ''Port of Spain'' class and built for the [[Trinidad and Tobago Coast Guard]]. Then, despite two of the vessels having been completed at the time and awaiting delivery, and with crew training ongoing in the UK,<ref name=completes_sea_trials>{{cite web |title=BAE may lose £150m ship deal |publisher=The News |year=2010 |url=http://www.portsmouth.co.uk/newshome/BAE-may-lose-150m-ship.6544236.jp |accessdate=2010-09-22}}</ref> the [[Government of Trinidad and Tobago|Government of the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago]] (GORTT) cancelled the order in September 2010.
In December 2011 it was reported that the [[Brazilian Navy]] were interested in buying the vessels, and possibly up to five additional vessels of the same design.<ref name=Brazil could buy the 3 BAE System's OPV that were canceled by Trinidad and Tobago>{{cite web |title=Brazil could buy the 3 BAE System's OPV that were canceled by Trinidad and Tobago|url=http://www.navyrecognition.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=238 |accessdate=2011-12-14}}</ref> The sale, for £133 million, was then confirmed on 2 January 2012.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-scotland-scotland-business-16383765 | work=BBC News | title=BAE Systems sells patrol vessels to Brazil | date=2012-01-02}}</ref>
''Amazonas'' was commissioned into the Brazilian Navy on 29 June in Portsmouth. During her one-month voyage to Brazil, she docked in the cities of [[Natal, Rio Grande do Norte]] and [[Salvador, Bahia]] in September, and was expected to arrive in Rio de Janeiro on 5 October.<ref>http://dialogo-americas.com/en_GB/articles/rmisa/features/regional_news/2012/10/03/feature-ex-3561</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.defencetalk.com/uk-welcomes-250th-brazilian-navy-sailor-for-maiden-sea-trials-47400/ |title=UK Welcomes 250th Brazilian Navy Sailor for Maiden Sea Trials |date=April 9, 2013}}</ref>
